case_name: Legal Representatives of the Plaintiff v. the Tenant

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1879 of 1971 was an appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated May 24, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in S.A. No. 178 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1879 of 1971. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated May 24, 1971 of the, Delhi High Court at New Delhi in S.A. No. 178 of 1970. B

facts.text: On June 28, 1962 a flat at New Rajinder Nagar, New Delhi was leased by the plaintiff to the defendant.

anchor.surface_text: On June 28, 1962 a flat at New Rajinder Nagar, New Delhi was leased by the plaintiff to the defendant. On failure of the, defendant to comply with two notices to quit plaintiff filed an ejectment application under section 14(1)(e) of the Delhi

facts.text: Defendant failed to comply with two notices to quit.

anchor.surface_text: On failure of the, defendant to comply with two notices to quit plaintiff filed an ejectment application under section 14(1)(e) of the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 (the Act). Possession was sought from the tenant on the ground that the premises were required by the plaintiff for occupation as a residence for himself and members of his family.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed an ejectment application under section 14(1)(e) of the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 seeking possession on ground of personal requirement for residence.

anchor.surface_text: On failure of the, defendant to comply with two notices to quit plaintiff filed an ejectment application under section 14(1)(e) of the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 (the Act). Possession was sought from the tenant on the ground that the premises were required by the plaintiff for occupation as a residence for himself and members of his family. The Additional Rent Controller, Delhi, dismissed the application on the preliminary ground that the notices to quit were not valid.

facts.text: Additional Rent Controller, Delhi dismissed the ejectment application on preliminary ground that notices to quit were not valid.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Rent Controller, Delhi, dismissed the application on the preliminary ground that the notices to quit were not valid. Plaintiff filed an appeal against that decision but during its pendency he died on August 22, 1968.

facts.text: Plaintiff died on August 22, 1968 during pendency of appeal against Additional Rent Controller's decision.

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiff filed an appeal against that decision but during its pendency he died on August 22, 1968. Appellants 1 to 4 who are the widow, son and two married daughters of the plaintiff applied for being brought on the record of the appeal as his legal representatives.

facts.text: Appellants 1 to 4 (widow, son and two married daughters of plaintiff) applied to be brought on record of the appeal as legal representatives.

anchor.surface_text: Appellants 1 to 4 who are the widow, son and two married daughters of the plaintiff applied for being brought on the record of the appeal as his legal representatives. The tenant opposed that application on the narrow ground that the son and daughter of a deceased daughter of the plaintiff ought also to have been impleaded to the application and since that was not done, the appeal had abated.

facts.text: Tenant opposed application to bring appellants 1-4 on record contending that son and daughter of deceased daughter of plaintiff also ought to be impleaded, otherwise appeal abated.

anchor.surface_text: The tenant opposed that application on the narrow ground that the son and daughter of a deceased daughter of the plaintiff ought also to have been impleaded to the application and since that was not done, the appeal had abated. By its order dated December 13, 1968 the Rent Control Tribunal, which was seized of the appeal allowed these two persons also to be impleaded as appellants.

facts.text: Rent Control Tribunal by order dated December 13, 1968 allowed son and daughter of deceased daughter to be impleaded as appellants 5 and 6.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated December 13, 1968 the Rent Control Tribunal, which was seized of the appeal allowed these two persons also to be impleaded as appellants. By a further order dated January 2, 1969 the, Tribunal set aside the decision recorded by the Additional Rent Controller on the preliminary issue and remanded the ejectment application for a decision on merits.

facts.text: Rent Control Tribunal by order dated January 2, 1969 set aside Additional Rent Controller's decision on preliminary issue and remanded ejectment application for decision on merits.

anchor.surface_text: By a further order dated January 2, 1969 the, Tribunal set aside the decision recorded by the Additional Rent Controller on the preliminary issue and remanded the ejectment application for a decision on merits. These two heirs are not appellant 5 and 6. Second appeal 107 of 1969 filed by the tenant against the order of remand, was dismissed by the High Court of Delhi on February 20, 1970.

facts.text: Tenant filed Second Appeal No. 107 of 1969 against Tribunal's remand order, dismissed by Delhi High Court on February 20, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: These two heirs are not appellant 5 and 6. Second appeal 107 of 1969 filed by the tenant against the order of remand, was dismissed by the High Court of Delhi on February 20, 1970. As the order of remand passed by the Rent Control Tribunal was not stayed during the pendency of the Second Appeal, the Additional Rent Controller proceeded with the ejectment application and had in the meanwhile passed an order of eviction against the tenant.

facts.text: No stay of Tribunal's remand order during pendency of Second Appeal, so Additional Rent Controller proceeded with ejectment application.

anchor.surface_text: As the order of remand passed by the Rent Control Tribunal was not stayed during the pendency of the Second Appeal, the Additional Rent Controller proceeded with the ejectment application and had in the meanwhile passed an order of eviction against the tenant. By his judgment of February 14, 1969 he held that the plaintiffs widow (appellant 1), his son (appellant 2), the sons wife and three. minor daughters of that couple required the premises bona-fide for their occupation.

facts.text: Additional Rent Controller by judgment dated February 14, 1969 passed order of eviction holding plaintiff's widow, son, son's wife and three minor daughters required premises bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: By his judgment of February 14, 1969 he held that the plaintiffs widow (appellant 1), his son (appellant 2), the sons wife and three. minor daughters of that couple required the premises bona-fide for their occupation. The tenant appealed against that decision and contended for the first time in appeal that the right to sue did not survive to the heirs of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Tenant appealed Additional Rent Controller's eviction order to Rent Control Tribunal and contended for first time that right to sue did not survive to heirs.

anchor.surface_text: The tenant appealed against that decision and contended for the first time in appeal that the right to sue did not survive to the. heirs of the plaintiff. The Rent Control Tribunal rejected that contention and confirmed the order of eviction on merits. In an appeal filed by the tenant (S.A.O. No. 178 of 1970) the High Court of Delhi took the view that the right to sue did not survive to the. heirs of the plaintiff and on that ground it dismissed the ejectment application, leaving it open to the heirs to bring a fresh proceeding founded on their own requirements.

facts.text: Rent Control Tribunal rejected tenant's contention that right to sue did not survive and confirmed eviction order on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The Rent Control Tribunal rejected that contention and confirmed the order of eviction on merits. In an appeal filed by the tenant (S.A.0. No. 178 of 1970) the High Court of Delhi took the view that the right to sue did not survive to the. heirs of the plaintiff and on that ground it dismissed the ejectment application, leaving it open to the heirs to bring a fresh proceeding founded on their own requirements.

facts.text: Delhi High Court in S.A.O. No. 178 of 1970 held right to sue did not survive to heirs and dismissed ejectment application.

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal filed by the tenant (S.A.0. No. 178 of 1970) the High Court of Delhi took the view that the right to sue did not survive to the. heirs of the plaintiff and on that ground it dismissed the ejectment application, leaving it open to the heirs to bring a fresh proceeding founded on their own requirements. The correctness of that decision is challenged by the plaintiffs heirs in this appeal special leave.

facts.text: Plaintiff's family consisted of wife, son, daughter-in-law and 3 minor grand-daughters, with only 2 rooms in possession which were inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: In column 19, the other relevant information is stated to be that the plaintiff had a large family consisting of his wife, son, daughter-in-law and 3 minor grand-daughters, and that the family had only 2 rooms in its possession, which were wholly inadequate for its requirements.

facts.text: Premises required bona fide by petitioner for occupation as residence for himself and family members, no other reasonable suitable accommodation.

anchor.surface_text: In column 18(a) of the ejectment application the ground for evicting the tenant is stated thus: The premises are required bonafide by the petitioner for occupation as a residence for himself and members of his family and that the petitioner has no other reasonable suitable residential accommodation.

facts.text: Appellants include widow (1), son (2), two married daughters (3,4), and two children of deceased daughter (5,6).

anchor.surface_text: Appellants 1 to 4 who are the widow, son and two married daughters of the plaintiff applied for being brought on the record of the appeal as his legal representatives. ... These two heirs are not appellant 5 and 6.

facts.text: Plaintiff owned the premises.

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiff, who owned the premises, was entitled under section 14(1)(e) of the Act to ask for possession thereof on the ground that his wife and the other members of his family dependent on him must live with him but that there was no enough space at his disposal to accommodate them.

facts.text: Tenant's Second Appeal against remand order was not stayed.

anchor.surface_text: As the order of remand passed by the Rent Control Tribunal was not stayed during the pendency of the Second Appeal,

facts.text: Delhi High Court left it open to heirs to bring fresh proceeding on their own requirements.

anchor.surface_text: leaving it open to the heirs to bring a fresh proceeding founded on their own requirements.

arguments.claim: The right to sue survives only if it means the right to the same relief asserted by the deceased plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: That is the formula contained in Order 22 Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, a formula simple in its wording but not simple in its application. The right to sue as said succinctly in Saraj Chandra v. Nani Mihan means the right to bring a suit asserting a right to the same relief which the deceased plaintiff asserted at the time of his death.

arguments.claim: The maxim actio personalis moritur cum persona applies as the requirement is a personal cause of action

anchor.surface_text: In some cases under the Rent Acts, the maxim actio-personalis moritur cum persona has been attempted to be applied on the death of a necessary party to a suit or proceeding but that oft-quoted maxim is oft misunderstood.

arguments.claim: Section 306 of the Indian Succession Act does not apply directly to determine survival here

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we find relevance in the provisions of section 306 of the Indian Succession Act, under which all demands whatsoever and all rights to prosecute or defend any action or special proceeding existing in favour of or against a person at the time of his decease, survive to and against his executors or administrators except causes of action for defamation and assault, or other personal injuries not causing the death of the party and except also cases where, after the death of the party, the relief sought could not be enjoyed or granting it would be nugatory.

arguments.claim: The pleaded requirement is the personal requirement of the plaintiff himself

arguments.claim: Continuing the proceedings by heirs would require fundamental alteration of pleadings beyond Order 6 Rule 17 CPC

anchor.surface_text: Such an alteration will fall beyond the scope of amendment of pleadings, permissible under a most liberal interpretation of order 6, Rule 17 of the Code of Civil procedure.

arguments.claim: The issues for determination change fundamentally upon substitution by heirs

arguments.claim: Precedents where death occurs after decree for possession are distinguishable as estate benefits from accrued decree

Several decisions were cited before us but those falling within the following categories are to be distinguished cases in which the death of the plaintiff occurred after a decree for possession was passed in his favour say, during the pendency of an appeal filed by the unsuccessful tenant

arguments.claim: Execution proceedings precedents are distinguishable as executing court cannot go behind the decree

anchor.surface_text: under section 14 1 e of the Delhi Rent Control Act, the landlord obtained an order of eviction on the ground of personal requirement but, he died before the order for eviction could be executed. ... Cases of the second category are distinguishable because the decisions therein are, by and large, based on the principle that an executing court has no jurisdiction to go behind the decree.

arguments.claim: Precedents where tenant dies are governed by different considerations as landlord's right continues against heirs

anchor.surface_text: Cases of the third category are governed by totally different considerations. The landlords right to evict the tenant on the grounds available under the Rent Act does not come to an end with the death of the tenant.

holdings.text: The right to sue means the right to bring a suit asserting a right to the same relief which the deceased plaintiff asserted at the time of his death.

anchor.surface_text: The right to sue as said succinctly in Saraj Chandra v. Nani Mihan 1 means the right to bring a suit asserting a right to the same relief which the deceased plaintiff asserted at the time of his death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Order 22 Rule 1 CPC and following precedent in Saraj Chandra v. Nani Mihan.

holdings.text: Thus, the requirement pleaded in the ejectment application and on which the plaintiff has founded his right to relief is his requirement, or to use an expression which will effectively bring out the real point, his personal requirement.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the requirement pleaded in the ejectment application and on which the plaintiff has founded his right to relief is his requirement, or to use an expression which will effectively bring out the real point, his personal requirement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based directly on pleadings in columns 18(a) and 19 of the ejectment application detailing plaintiff's own need and family.

holdings.text: Such a personal cause of action must perish with the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: That the members of his family must reside with him is his requirement, not theirs. Such a personal cause of action must perish with the plaintiff .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Personal requirement under s.14(1)(e) is not the same relief for legal representatives; applies test from O.22 r.1 CPC.

The appellants emergence in the proceedings will require the determination of wholly different and distinct issues.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Heirs' requirements and accommodations differ from plaintiff's; new issues on their bona fides etc.

holdings.text: Cases of the first category are distinguishable because the decisions therein are explicable on the basis, though not always so expressed, that the estate is entitled to the benefit which, under a decree, has accrued in favour of the plaintiff and therefore the legal representatives are entitled to defend further proceedings, like an appeal, which constitute a challenge to that benefit.

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiff, who owned the premises, was entitled under section 14 1   e  of the Act to ask for possession thereof on the ground that his wife and the other members of his family dependent on him must live with him but that there was number enough space at his disposal to accommodate them. Section 14 1  e  provides to the extent material for the present purposes, that the Controller may make an order for possession on the ground that the premises let for residential purposes are required bonafide by the landlord for occupation as a residence for himself or for any member of his family dependent on him, if he is the owner thereof and that the landlord has numberother reasonably suitable residential accommodation. [...] Several decisions were cited before us but those falling within the following categories are to be distinguished cases in which the death of the plaintiff occurred after a decree for possession was passed in his favour say, during the pendency of an appeal filed by the unsuccessful tenant [...] Cases of the first category are distinguishable because the decisions therein are explicable on the basis, though not always so expressed, that the estate is entitled to the benefit which, under a decree, has accrued in favour of the plaintiff

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-decree death allows estate to protect accrued benefit under decree.

holdings.text: Cases of the second category are distinguishable because the decisions therein are, by and large, based on the principle that an executing court has no jurisdiction to go behind the decree.

anchor.surface_text: under section 14  1   e  of the Delhi Rent Control Act, the landlord obtained an orde [...] Cases of the second category are distinguishable because the decisions therein are, by and large, based on the principle that an executing court has no jurisdiction to go behind the decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executing court bound by decree terms, cannot reassess personal requirement post-death.

holdings.text: Cases of the third category are governed by totally different considerations. The landlords right to evict the tenant on the grounds available under the Rent Act does not come to an end with the death of the tenant.

anchor.surface_text: Cases of the third category are governed by totally different considerations. The landlords right to evict the tenant on the grounds available under the Rent Act does not come to an end with the death of the tenant. That right is enforceable against those in whom the tenants interest resides for the time being.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Landlord's eviction right persists against tenant's heirs unlike landlord's personal right.

precedents.cited_proposition: landlord's need for premises for himself and wife under section 14(1)(e) survives to widow
precedents.cited_holding: the wife was a member of the landlords family and as the need of the landlord for the premises was assessed to be both for himself and his wife, the cause of action consisted of the need of both and therefore it survived to the widow

precedents.case_name: Smt Dhan Devi and Anr v Bakhshi Ram and Anr
precedents.cited_proposition: rights of landlord-decree-holder under eviction order are heritable and devolve on legal representatives after death
precedents.cited_holding: the word landlord in the East Punjab Act includes his successors-in-interest and that the rights of a landlord-decree-holder under an order of eviction obtained by him are heritable and devolve after his death on his legal representatives
